abstract: Architectural and systems-engineering considerations and tradeoffs are primary design-drivers in Martian and lunar missions, entailing studies of such fundamental choices as the use of rapid trajectories in the course of which crews live in zero-g or slower trajectories in which crews are subjected to artificial gravity. The best use of transportation way-points, the integration of launch vehicles with spacecraft of various configurations, and the incorporation of such advanced concepts as solar sail propulsion, are additional considerations to be studied. The planning of lunar and Martian missions must always take into account the extent to which local resources can diminish earth-supplied logistics requirements.
title: Looking at the architecture
